record.title: Kasey Mohammad interviewed by Devin Becker
record.transcript:
DB: I missed like the first 5 minutes of what we're trying to interview.
KM: Oh, no!
DB: I think I got it on one device, though—but not recorded.
This doesn't end up like the most reliable thing. So...
OK, should I close that or...?
KM You might just so people don't bug us.
DB: OK
Here we go...
Alright, so we begin. Thank you very much for agreeing to do this, KC.
KM: My pleasure for coming.
DB: Would you please state, for the camera, your name, your date of birth, and the location we're at right now?
KM: Kasey Silem Mohammad. October 10, 1962. We're at Southern Oregon University in Central Hall.
DB: So, the first section is kind of short-answer. It's meant to get a sense of you digital practices now. So, we'll just kind of go through this and we'll talk more about the composition.
So, what genres do you work in?
KM: Poetry
DB: OK, and that's your primary genre?
KM: Yeah
DB: What kinds of devices do you own, or have access to for writing?
KM: This laptop, a MacBook. That's... I mean, that's about it, other than whatever scratchpad I might put my note my idea in.
DB: So you use only that one? Do you write on the phone? Do you write on any other things?
KM: Usually, not. I mean, the laptop is the main instrument.
DB: The laptop is the main instrument?
KM: Yeah
DB: And you have an Apple.
KM: Uh-hmm
DB: Do you then....You said you use some note papers sometimes?
KM: I mean, if I'm somewhere and all I have is a piece of scratch paper because I'm in a meeting and I get an idea. But that's... I don't really do that often.
DB: OK, so it's pretty primarily on that computer?
KM: That—that is mostly it.
DB: OK, do you have any... I mean, for your writing... This is where we get to the... Do you ever take like pre-writing or notes for it, or ...?
KM: Because of the kind of writing I do, that usually doesn't come in to play.
DB: Yeah
KM: Which I think will become clear when we talk about the actual composition.
DB: OK
In what format do you save your digital files?
KM: Word
DB: Word doc
KM: Uh-hmm
DB: Do you save individual works as you go along, or do you simply save over what you've written? Do you have like... Do you save like drafts?
KM: Oh, no. I don't... I probably should, but I almost never save drafts. Just open up a doc and write over it until I think it's finished.
DB: OK, and what are your naming conventions for your files?
KM: Usually the name of the poem, followed by the file name.
DB: Yeah... But... And so, because you don't use drafts, you're just like...It's just the one?
KM: Yeah, I don't rename it once I've drafted, or anything. It just stays the same.
DB: Do you ever.... Do you print out your writing to revise it?
KM: No, not typically.
DB: OK
KM: What exactly... I mean, I might do that on occasional like with an essay because I need to be able to.. It's easier on the eyes. But the poems are usually shorter, and again because of the specific nature of the composition, in some case, you will see it's like I can't revise it really well at all if it's not on a computer.
DB: Yeah
And so, if you don't use... Do you ever save any paper copies of interim drafts?
KM: Usually not. I think the only exception to that is maybe I have some paper copies somewhere of something I wrote in college (and hope no one will ever sees—maybe it's the way they're written. I don't ever bother to try and describe them digitally).
DB: So, do you back up your work?
KM: Yeah, when I remember. Yeah.
DB: And how often do you do that?
KM: Oh, gosh. Conscious of streaming— I don't know. I probably need to do it right now—excuse me. I really... It's very erratic.
DB: OK
So, do you use... You don't use like a Cloud-based...Do you have like Dropbox or anything? I mean, is that...?
KM: You know, I've got a server here on campus. It's a backup server everything it into. It's very simple. All I need to do is drag stuff right now (and I could do it to stop bothering about it).
I've also got an external hard drive at home.
DB: You have an external... And that's if you're going to archive it, if you're going to back it up, that's where you put the work.
OK
And say... Do you have like a separate thing for ... Once a poem is finished, do you move it to a different folder, or are there any...?
KM: Yeah, I've gotten kind of lax on it. I need to go in and update it, but typically what it'll be is: I have a
(05:00) folder (a main poetry folder) and within that, if there is a specific categories for certain projects, I'll divide them in to that (like a book project, or whatever). And if something is published, typically, I'll put a copy of it in the Published folder, and then there would be like an Ongoing, or In-process, folder.
DB: Yeah
Do you keep print copies of final drafts? Do you print them out?
KM: Not usually.
DB: And how about the media you've been published in—do you keep the journals or... in a sort of space?
KM: I do, yeah. I have a shelf full of journals and books.
DB: OK
So, do you have any standard practices for archiving digitally or physically? Would you say...?
KM: Maybe explain what you mean a little more.
DB: I guess... I mean, do you have... Like when you put it on... Do you have like a certain kind of way you go where you put it on an external hard drive, or you put all your papers, or your books, in a certain shelf and that's kind of like your archive?
KM: Yeah. Right, yes. Like I said, I do have a shelf in my living room. It's like most of the journals and books, anthologies, I've been published in. And as far as I said for the digital files, yeah, there's usually a Published folder—which is way behind being updated.
DB: So, have you ever received or sought out information about digital archiving, or any sort of practices in that way?
KM: Not really, no. No.
DB: OK
Would you be interested in receiving information?
KM: Possibly, yeah.
DB: OK, that was kind of the basics.
And so, this gets more to the kind of like your trajectory as a writer. So, it starts off kind of getting a larger arc of it. So, how long have you been writing "professionally"?
KM: I'd say since roughly '98 or '99
DB: '98 or '99
And could you kind of give us a sense of like the arc of your career over that time period?
KM Sure.
That's when I was just finishing grad school (and procrastinating on finishing my dissertation). So, I kind of went back to my long-time interest in contemporary poetry. And I think I had tried to send a few things out to get them published over the years, a few times, without any success or sense of direction about it.
And then during all this time (wasting period), I became aware of electronic journals for that publishing authors that I liked, but before that I hadn't known even how to submit work, you know, to the same journals that would publish poems I liked because, you know, I had tried—missing, for example, 5, 10 years before to submit to magazines that I knew published language poetry and things like that. And typically, I really did get no response, or maybe a slip saying, "Sorry, this journal is no longer in circulation," because the only way I heard about them—the first place—was from the library copy... I had no contact with any of the people involved.
So, the internet changed that. I've published in a few online journals and made contacts with poets that way. And then it was pretty rapid—from an initial Chap book that was published by Kenning Editions (ran by Patrick Durgin in 2001) called Hovercraft, then my first book (in 2003) was Dearhead Nation from Tougher Disguises Press by James Mets. Then another book (next year), Mike McGhee's combo books A Thousand Devils; a couple books at the end of the decade from Ed Rodsmith's Jury, and lots of journals and anthologies in the middle there. And a few other Chap book that I've neglected to mention.
KM: And then... And now, the project that you're working on the Sonograms?
DB: That's my chief project, yeah.
KM: OK, but you have other ones going?
DB: Well, that's the one that I consciously think of as a project that I'm in the middle of. Occasionally, I'll write something just on a whim, but yeah, that's the main project.
So, we'll sort of talk about in the.... couple of different steps in the writing process and then we're going to go through kind of how it was in the early stages of your writing and how it's changed. And so, my kind of way of thinking about it is there's the compositional stage (which is where you're kind of creating it), and then you have the revisions stage, and then you kind of have the organizational/archival stage (which is when you're putting it in to books and getting it published).
So, those are the 3 stages to talk about. And then how those have changed over the course of... Sort of like 3 by 3.
KM: Sure
DB: So, when you first started writing (and this is even before you started writing professionally, maybe before when you were trying to find those language journals, or language poetry journals). I mean, what was your composition"? Or, how were you writing, like what were you doing?
KM: That's really hard to reconstruct something that long ago.
I don't think I have much of a method. I think I was really just kind of feeling around in the dark.
(10:00) So, I took a couple of... You know, I took a couple of creative writing classes in junior college. I took one as an undergrad, but didn't really work for me. That didn't do anything for me. Yeah, and I just occasionally feel inspired to write something. I mean, I was very shapeless.
DB: Yeah
So, how did you come to find the writing that you like? I mean, to find the language poetry, to find the journals that you were sending out?
KM: I don't remember what led me to it, but I remember just surfing the web. I think one of the journals, one of the very first journals that caught my attention was Combo by Mike McGhee. They published Clark Coolidge and other language poets (and younger poets I hadn't heard of), and then at least some of it was online (I think if I remember correctly it was like limited to digital sampling). And I just emailed them saying, "Hey, I just want to go about submitting any work," or anything like that. They liked the work, and I was published in them a couple of times.
It's the same thing with Kenning (which is also a journal—Patrick Durgin's journal).
I think my first publication actually was in Fourteen Hills from San Francisco State. I went to a group reading for the contributors to that issue and met a lot of Bay Area poets. So, I established a connection with...
I forget what the original question was now...
DB: Oh, it's fine. That's actually kind of what I'm interested in.
And then... And so, your writing styles in the beginning, the ways of composition, you are kind of formless and then you started accommodating...
KM: Oh, yeah, yeah
DB: How did they start to progress then? I mean, what was sort of the next step in...?
KM: Sure, that's actually pretty easy to answer because it's kind of, at least so far, it's been kind of a really distinct, 3-stage process.
DB: Oh, great!
KM: Actually according to the terms of the question.
So, that earliest work—and this would be everything up through the period I am talking about—was just basically (I don't know how quite to describe it) organic, or free-hand, and you know, just making stuff up and writing it down. Words would come in to my head, and I would put them on the page.
So, typically, I would just type and it would be like trying to compose a musical piece, or something—like, what should go after this; how can I complete this rhythm (or set of images), or something like that.
And then that began to change with (again 2000/2001) when I met Gary Sullivan and other members of the Flarf Group—and that itself has kind of like 2 stages. At first, I became acquainted with Gary's writing on an email list that we were both on, and just for a joke he wrote some New Year's poem (or something like that) that he called a Flarf poem. Flarf was the invented name for the method. It was basically just writing the stupidest, most shapeless thing you could think of—so it was full of non-sense and obscenities, and phatic noises with no real shape, or form, other than just basically roughly being broken in to lines.
He and I (and a few other people) started doing this for fun and we created our own email list just so we can do it (and I'm sure the full origin, stories out there about...) ....
DB: Yeah, and just for my clarification. It started on a different email list and then it moved to its own?
KM: That's right, and I guess really it started the list (if I'm correct—I think this is what Gary related to me)—that he sent a poem in to one of those online vanity price things [inaudible 13:55] .com (and the short version) trying to get rejected. So, he wrote just the stupidest thing he could think of—and "it was accepted for consideration for the anthology" which he then pay for if you're actually dumb enough to go through with that.
So, that was the origin of that. Now, they just started writing them more on the email list even after he realized he couldn't get rejected—because it was fun. So, a group of us that were on this list... And so eventually (I think it was Drew Gardner who introduced a method in the middle of this shapeless writing) of using Google search results. Just going in to Google page, doing usually a combination search for like two or three terms that you don't expect to see on the same page together, and then using that initial search result page as a base from which to collage excerpts—not following the links, just...
DB: Just the language that shows up in the Google
(15:00) like the caches, or the...
KM: That's right, yeah!
So, my typical process... This is the 2nd stage—the big 2nd stage where, for 10 years, I basically just wrote Google collages. The typical process for that was I would copy however many pages of the search result page (next page, next page of about 10 or 100 results show up on the page), and the page turn in to word, and start chiseling it down (rearranging it, shuffling the contents—occasionally cheating a little bit, putting a connector words or something or maybe altering a word in just a slightly different grammatical form or something).
But that gets back to what we are saying about not doing print revisions because really everything is done with (kind of like refrigerator magnets) just shuffling around. And I guess printing out a page, I can look at that thing and, "Well, if I brought some of this down here, see it all"—but I never did that, so...
DB: No, right, right. I mean, it makes it kind of it's computer generated.
KM: Yeah, and part of the fun of it was using the computer as a kind of canvas.
DB: Yeah
KM: There's kind of something pleasing about pulling the components around—almost physically moving them around that digital space.
DB: And when you're copying the page, do you just say CTRL + Alt, grab it, drop it in? Do you get images and what-not with that? Or do you just like drag the thing up and just get the text and paste it?
KM: Yeah, I typically just select the whole page, copy, paste. I mean, there weren't any images because it was just the result page.
DB: Just the result page, OK
KM: Right
What you would get is a lot of the red or blue text, or purple text, the URLs and headers, and things like that, but typically I would just... You know, first stage of going through the manuscript would be to remove all of that kind of junk text. It wasn't all junk but...
DB: Right
KM: But, yeah they were just numbers and code, and so all I had left were recognizable words, maybe numbers.
DB: And in getting rid of that (of that junk text) were you reading it at the same time or were you starting to kind of get a sense of what you have gotten? Or was it just kind of a rope—"Let's get rid of this and I'll look at it"?
KM: I think... Based on my memory, it'd be a rope thing of just, "First, let's get rid of everything I know is not actual, (in most cases) not useable text." I mean, there might be some little strings of code where I think, "Oh, that's kind of cool just by itself. I'll leave that in," but it was mostly an automatic process of just, "Let me reduce it to just letters and black text (as opposed to colored, link text).
And then from that stage of... I don't know how interesting this could possibly be to anybody but...
DB: I'm interested!
KM: What would be left after that would be a lot of things like ellipses, or dashes because there'd be partial phrases, and then ellipses, and then a beginning of another phrase--that'd be how the search results would be arranged on the page. So then I might just have to say, "OK, I might get rid of all or most of the ellipses or dashes" and I would also, I know, go through (just for the sake of composition) change case—select everything and then change case to lowercase just to get rid of all the blocks of long list of caps that are kind of unwieldy.
And then later in that process of composition, I might change some letters back to caps, but typically for whatever reason, the default form after the poem would be no caps unless they're required convention (by which I mean like proper names and things like that). Now, I wouldn't capitalize the beginning of a line or anything like that.
So, I'll just start... Basically, once I'm ready to actually start composing the poem I would have however many pages of full of lowercase language in black and white.
DB: Yeah
And so for the dashes and ellipses and what-not, you'd just do a Find All and delete them all?
KM: Yeah, that would be the quick way. I learned that pretty quickly. I would just, "Find this, replace with nothing" until I just have words to fill those parts, maybe some numerals.
DB: Yeah!
And so, you would get to the.... And so... I mean, that's almost kind of your pre-writing stage in some ways, and then you're to the point where you're composing the poem or whatever word you want to use. I mean, what words do you use, I guess?
KM: Yeah, and then after that.. I mean, once... Just because of the nature of the way it was copied on the page with, usually what I end up with would be something like a tercets, or something that looked on the page already kind of like tercets which is why a lot of the poems (not all of them) end up being in tercets, and I would just keep that—and sometimes 2 lines, sometimes 3 lines, sometimes longer, and
(20:00) sometimes more (longer) stanzas.
But sometimes, just that accidental form would give me kind of a starting point like, "OK, I've got groups of 3 lines, but I want to move this line from this one up here to this other one. And then balance out the other one with the other line (or phrase)." Like I said, it would be like refrigerator magnets with all those sometimes full phrases instead of just individual words.
And in the middle of that process, I usually get rid of most of the language—some of the language I couldn't figure out what interesting thing I could do with, or would be interesting.
So, the finished poems might be anywhere from a third of a page to several pages long, but I'd be starting sometimes with like 10 pages.
DB: And you just go and delete, delete, delete?
KM: Uh-hmm, and rearrange, shuffle.
DB: And so, what were the phrases or the words, or groupings, that would catch your eye or catch your ear? I mean, which was it catching, I guess, too?
KM: I'd say earlier in the process, it had more to do with the original search for terms I used. So, for example, my first book Deerhead Nation involved a bunch of searched usually included among other terms the term deerhead. So, for that, I was obviously motivated to keep deerhead a lot of the time so I can keep that theme going. Or sometimes I would think of a phrase I think was funny or bizarre and I'd want that to be a title, and I want to keep a few instances of those words in the poem.
I'd say it's like a... Several years along the process, I got to the point where I didn't really care if the original term showed up at all. I just wanted to create kind of a lyric construct, but that was limited for its sources—that bank of terms.
DB: What do you think got you to that sort of preference?
KM: No idea
DB: No idea
KM: I think just getting bored with the regularity of the earlier process. So, I think, it worked pretty well for me, yeah, with some of the original first projects because they were kind of thematically motivated. You know, the deerhead thing was supposed to be kind of a metaphor for Imperialism or something, I don't know...
DB: Yeah
KM: But as it went on, I just really became more concerned with just wanting a verbal shape or sculpture that I found interesting.
DB: And do you find that those later poems are more like readable, or... I mean...?
KM: Probably not. I mean, that's a good... I'm laughing, but I mean... You know, one person's definition of readable is very different from another's because, in all honesty, some people would look at whether it's early in the stage or later in the stage and think, "This isn't poetry. This is just spam (or something)—garbage from the internet."
I don't even think that the divide is along the experimental or traditional, necessarily, because frankly a lot of the biggest critics of Flarf are experimental poets.
DB: Right
KM: So, I think it really just have to do with whether a person has that kind of mind that likes arrangement, in that sense, rather than... Let me rephrase that. I think it depends whether someone's drawn to verbal arrangement over and above verbal theme.
I mean, that's what drew me originally to poets like Clark Coolidge and other language poets, or... You know, it didn't matter what it said in the traditional sense. I was interested like, "Wow! I can put those words in that place!"
So, I don't really know what's readable to the "average person" because I don't think there's an average person.
DB: Yeah
I guess, in terms of your own reading or in terms of your own compositions, I mean, when you're making those things, did you find those later poems to be more pleasurable to make? I mean, was there like... I don't know. You said there was more of a lyric bend to them.
KM: Yeah, but I don't know if other people would see those lyrics necessarily. But, yeah, I think so. I think... Inevitably, it became almost (at least from my perspective) more traditional. I mean, yeah, I don't think other people are going to think, "Yeah, you call this traditional?" but I felt like I was kind of going back to the kinds of things that pleased me about older forms of poetry. So, even if the poems themselves have like ridiculous vocabulary and images, junk food, or porn site terminology (or whatever else comes off the internet), I would be looking for rhythm—I would be looking.
I'm very influenced by somebody like Clark Coolidge on that level—kind of like the jazz influence mode of composition.
DB: So, I guess... I mean, how are you constructing your lines, I mean, if you're looking for that sort of rhythm?
KM: I mean... I guess, the lines are really just determined by the
(25:00) shape of the phrases. I mean, for me, the rhythm comes outwards, from words. It's not like a pentameter rhythm or something that's determined by a set length. It's a not-nap [inaudible 25:13] project, not-nose prose [inaudible 25:15]
DB: But then, were you grabbing... When you grab a phrase or a few phrases, we're those automatically lines or would you break those into different lines.
KM: It really depends, but I usually do a lot of breaking. I mean, there's a sense on which the whole process is kind of unnecessary, I mean, because ultimately what I was doing was just manipulating the results so much that... I mean, I would think all the time that I really don't need to go to the internet except at the level of just, I think, vocabulary.
DB: Yeah, yeah
KM: And maybe beyond that, just a little syntactical clusters--"Oh, wow! Look at these 4 words in a row. I would never have come up with these 4 words in a row on my own just trying to think of something." So, what I was looking for is just really pallet full of colors—colors I couldn't think of by myself because, you know, human being would think of putting those things in a poem because they're not that, they're something else at that stage.
DB: So, in terms of like your revision strategies for these poems, I mean, in the early stages you had a more (I'm sort of recapping) intent towards representing the search in some very fundamental way, and then later it started to become...you wanted to kind of represent an accumulation and arrangement more lyrically, or more in a way that kind of traditional in your traditions of poetry.
KM: But in the one constant was the importance of the idea that was generated by the search, and I think that was a factor for the re-... I think, I don't see the need to mask the method. I think, one of the pleasures, for me, of reading other work like that by other people is knowing, "Oh, they did this by using a particular procedure." And I'm still most interested in how the finished work affects me, but the knowledge that it was created in a certain way is something I can't separate, and I don't want to separate.
So, you know, I would frame the work all the way through. It's like, if I were to mention it which I had occasion to do in the beginning of the book if ever-- "This was creating using Google search methods." So, I think it helps people going in to it with that knowledge, but like you're saying, I didn't necessarily want the search to retain some imprint of it—all the original conditions of the search—maybe in the first book, to some extent, yeah.
For example, in Deerhead Nation, I not only kept a lot more longer clusters—the original syntactic clusters—but I would keep a bunch of ellipses and create visual groupings with them. All these kind of graphic reminders of what the process was. I just felt less inclined to do that as I went on because it didn't seem necessary for the different kinds of poems I was getting in to.
DB: Right, right
What about the prose poems in this traditions? How did those come about?
KM: Oh, yeah! I mean, same thing but there the original search terms did remain much more important because, I mean, you have a phrase like "and then she said" or something very fixed and obviously in order to keep the shape throughout the poem, I'm going to have to keep coming back to that tag. Then there the goal is usually to make it seem seamless like this is the one subject saying something over and over again. So, yeah, that would be an exception whenever I do... although I think I also did some prose once where I didn't stick that much to whatever original, grammatical framing. I don't remember off hand how...which ones.
DB: Yeah
So...
[I'm trying to think how to phrase this one] And then...
[So, we're at that...] Well, I mean... I guess this is one of the questions I ask a lot. It's: were these revisions driven by sound? I mean, were you reading them out loud to get a better kind of rhythm or did you have like meanings or themes that you wanted to, let's say... I mean, especially it seems...?
KM: Yeah, that's a good question.
I think sound was probably usually, at least, tied for the primary way there.
DB: Yeah, and what would determine a line break then, in terms of sound?
KM: That's a difficult question even for like traditional methods of writing, right?
DB: It's an impossible question.
KM: You know what drives me crazy on workshop when I'm teaching? It's like on the one hand wanting people to think about line breaks and what motivates them in what they do, and the other hand getting so tired of getting bogged down in completely arbitrary theories of like the line break because, in some ways,
(30:00) it's like the very important thing is just totally random. I mean, not in every poem obviously and, of course, especially if you're working on a fixed form, it's taken care of but free-verse or procedural (or other kinds of things where the line breaks are kind of post-facto consideration). I mean, really? It's just going on my nerve, you know. Just what strikes me at the moment is seeming like the good way to keep the rhythm going, or to create a [inaudible 30:29] rhythm, or do a little both depending on where I am in the poem.
DB: Sure
Did you... And so, for these... OK, what would be the phrase that you would use? I mean, you said it's collage. .You say it's Google collage. I mean, I've seen Google sculpt. I've seen [inaudible 30:46] poetry--
KM: Yeah, Google sculpt is the term I kind of put out there for it.
DB: OK
And then... So, that's the one you sort of prefer saying. It's like Google sculpting—I mean, sculpting being collage works?
KM: Collage works, too, yeah.
DB: Collage works, OK.
And did you save... Like do you know what the terms are for each poem, and is there somewhere where that's recorded?
KM: No. Sometimes I think about that, "Why didn't I keep a record of how exactly this came about?" I'm too kind of absent-minded and lazy for that.
DB: That's OK
Probably have to recreate it someday by using simulator or--
KM: Oh, you can't because the internet has completely changed, right?
DB: Yeah
KM: It's gone forever.
DB: I know, I know. It's so fascinating.
And then... So, I guess those are... That's... So, we've moved from the first stage to the second stage to then the 2 stages of that. The latter stage of that having run up to about 10 years you said?
KM: Something like that, yeah. So, like I'm writing just free-form or however you want to describe it from like '98 to 2000. So, that's very short phase. The second book, A Thousand Devils, was kind of stuff left over from that stage. So, even though that came out in 2004, most of it have been written quite earlier.
DB: And the Hovercraft is also that certain stage?
KM: Yeah, that's that initial stage.
DB: OK, and then the second stage starts with Deerhead Nation?
KM: Uh-hmm, through Breathalyzer and The Front.
DB: And The Front, OK.
And then... And now, the project... And so, this third section then is the Sonograms?
KM: Yeah
DB: So, how did that project come about?
KM: And I should just... I mean, just discuss what I say, I'm calling these stages just as a convenient way of separating different times.
DB: Well, it helps my kind of--
KM: Yeah, yeah. I just wanted... I don't think of it necessarily like, "Oh, this is the, you know, initiatory stage and I developed in to this." This is just when I happened to start doing and stopped doing.
DB: Yeah, no. Not compression. It's more of just--
KM: Yeah
So, yeah, Sonograms... I'd say... I forgot what year. Maybe... It's embarrassingly a long time now because I've been working very slowly on it. I've been a really lazy poet.
DB: The best poets are.
KM: And so, I mean, it would've been finished a long time ago if I kept it in schedule, but I'm a little over halfway thru. I think I started (I don't know) 2008, or something like that, and it started... It was like National Poetry month, and I was looking for an idea for like—just some quick and easy gimmick to allow me to write a poem a day. And I thought, "I could do something with Shakespeare sonnets." It's like go to the internet and find a sonnet, copy it, and post it/ paste it in to a Word doc--"OK, what can I do in the next 5 or 10 minutes using this as my source?" Say, "here I wrote a poem for this silly tradition."
And I just started kind of shuffling it and playing with it with my cursor, thinking.
